// type_traits.h
18
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
19
//
20
// This file contains C++11-compatible versions of standard <type_traits> API
21
// functions for determining the characteristics of types. Such traits can
22
// support type inference, classification, and transformation, as well as
23
// make it easier to write templates based on generic type behavior.
24
//
25
// See https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/header/type_traits
26
//
27
// WARNING: use of many of the constructs in this header will count as "complex
28
// template metaprogramming", so before proceeding, please carefully consider
29
// https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Template_metaprogramming
30
//
31
// WARNING: using template metaprogramming to detect or depend on API
32
// features is brittle and not guaranteed. Neither the standard library nor
33
// Abseil provides any guarantee that APIs are stable in the face of template
34
// metaprogramming. Use with caution.
35
#ifndef ABSL_META_TYPE_TRAITS_H_
36
#define ABSL_META_TYPE_TRAITS_H_
37
38
#include <stddef.h>
39
#include <functional>
40
#include <type_traits>
41
42
#include "absl/base/config.h"
43
44
namespace absl {
45

// Defined and documented later on in this file.
47
template <typename T>
48
struct is_trivially_move_assignable;
49

namespace type_traits_internal {
51
52
// Silence MSVC warnings about the destructor being defined as deleted.
53
#if defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__GNUC__)
54
#pragma warning(push)
55
#pragma warning(disable : 4624)
56
#endif  // defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__GNUC__)
57
58
template <class T>
59
union SingleMemberUnion {
60
  T t;
61
};
62
63
// Restore the state of the destructor warning that was silenced above.
64
#if defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__GNUC__)
65
#pragma warning(pop)
66
#endif  // defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__GNUC__)
67
68
template <class T>
69
struct IsTriviallyMoveAssignableReference : std::false_type {};
70
71
template <class T>
72
struct IsTriviallyMoveAssignableReference<T&>
73
    : absl::is_trivially_move_assignable<T>::type {};
74
75
template <class T>
76
struct IsTriviallyMoveAssignableReference<T&&>
77
    : absl::is_trivially_move_assignable<T>::type {};
78
79
template <typename... Ts>
80
struct VoidTImpl {
81
  using type = void;
82
};
83
84
// This trick to retrieve a default alignment is necessary for our
85
// implementation of aligned_storage_t to be consistent with any implementation
86
// of std::aligned_storage.
87
template <size_t Len, typename T = std::aligned_storage<Len>>
88
struct default_alignment_of_aligned_storage;
89
90
template <size_t Len, size_t Align>
91
struct default_alignment_of_aligned_storage<Len,
92
                                            std::aligned_storage<Len, Align>> {
93
  static constexpr size_t value = Align;
94
};

100
// NOTE: The `is_detected` family of templates here differ from the library
101
// fundamentals specification in that for library fundamentals, `Op<Args...>` is
102
// evaluated as soon as the type `is_detected<Op, Args...>` undergoes
103
// substitution, regardless of whether or not the `::value` is accessed. That
104
// is inconsistent with all other standard traits and prevents lazy evaluation
105
// in larger contexts (such as if the `is_detected` check is a trailing argument
106
// of a `conjunction`. This implementation opts to instead be lazy in the same
107
// way that the standard traits are (this "defect" of the detection idiom
108
// specifications has been reported).
109
110
template <class Enabler, template <class...> class Op, class... Args>
111
struct is_detected_impl {
112
  using type = std::false_type;
113
};
114
115
template <template <class...> class Op, class... Args>
116
struct is_detected_impl<typename VoidTImpl<Op<Args...>>::type, Op, Args...> {
117
  using type = std::true_type;
118
};
119
120
template <template <class...> class Op, class... Args>
121
struct is_detected : is_detected_impl<void, Op, Args...>::type {};
122
123
template <class Enabler, class To, template <class...> class Op, class... Args>
124
struct is_detected_convertible_impl {
125
  using type = std::false_type;
126
};
127
128
template <class To, template <class...> class Op, class... Args>
129
struct is_detected_convertible_impl<
130
    typename std::enable_if<std::is_convertible<Op<Args...>, To>::value>::type,
131
    To, Op, Args...> {
132
  using type = std::true_type;
133
};
134
135
template <class To, template <class...> class Op, class... Args>
136
struct is_detected_convertible
137
    : is_detected_convertible_impl<void, To, Op, Args...>::type {};
138
139
template <typename T>
140
using IsCopyAssignableImpl =
141
    decltype(std::declval<T&>() = std::declval<const T&>());
142
143
template <typename T>
144
using IsMoveAssignableImpl = decltype(std::declval<T&>() = std::declval<T&&>());
145
146
}  // namespace type_traits_internal
147
148
template <typename T>
149
struct is_copy_assignable : type_traits_internal::is_detected<
150
                                type_traits_internal::IsCopyAssignableImpl, T> {
151
};
152
153
template <typename T>
154
struct is_move_assignable : type_traits_internal::is_detected<
155
                                type_traits_internal::IsMoveAssignableImpl, T> {
156
};

158
// void_t()
159
//
160
// Ignores the type of any its arguments and returns `void`. In general, this
161
// metafunction allows you to create a general case that maps to `void` while
162
// allowing specializations that map to specific types.
163
//
164
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++17
165
// `std::void_t` metafunction.
166
//
167
// NOTE: `absl::void_t` does not use the standard-specified implementation so
168
// that it can remain compatible with gcc < 5.1. This can introduce slightly
169
// different behavior, such as when ordering partial specializations.
170
template <typename... Ts>
171
using void_t = typename type_traits_internal::VoidTImpl<Ts...>::type;
172
173
// conjunction
174
//
175
// Performs a compile-time logical AND operation on the passed types (which
176
// must have  `::value` members convertible to `bool`. Short-circuits if it
177
// encounters any `false` members (and does not compare the `::value` members
178
// of any remaining arguments).
179
//
180
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++17
181
// `std::conjunction` metafunction.
182
template <typename... Ts>
183
struct conjunction;
184
185
template <typename T, typename... Ts>
186
struct conjunction<T, Ts...>
187
    : std::conditional<T::value, conjunction<Ts...>, T>::type {};
188
189
template <typename T>
190
struct conjunction<T> : T {};
191
192
template <>
193
struct conjunction<> : std::true_type {};
194
195
// disjunction
196
//
197
// Performs a compile-time logical OR operation on the passed types (which
198
// must have  `::value` members convertible to `bool`. Short-circuits if it
199
// encounters any `true` members (and does not compare the `::value` members
200
// of any remaining arguments).
201
//
202
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++17
203
// `std::disjunction` metafunction.
204
template <typename... Ts>
205
struct disjunction;
206
207
template <typename T, typename... Ts>
208
struct disjunction<T, Ts...> :
209
      std::conditional<T::value, T, disjunction<Ts...>>::type {};
210
211
template <typename T>
212
struct disjunction<T> : T {};
213
214
template <>
215
struct disjunction<> : std::false_type {};
216
217
// negation
218
//
219
// Performs a compile-time logical NOT operation on the passed type (which
220
// must have  `::value` members convertible to `bool`.
221
//
222
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++17
223
// `std::negation` metafunction.
224
template <typename T>
225
struct negation : std::integral_constant<bool, !T::value> {};
226
227
// is_function()
228
//
229
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is a function type.
230
//
231
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
232
// `std::is_function()` metafunction for platforms that have incomplete C++11
233
// support (such as libstdc++ 4.x).
234
//
235
// This metafunction works because appending `const` to a type does nothing to
236
// function types and reference types (and forms a const-qualified type
237
// otherwise).
238
template <typename T>
239
struct is_function
240
    : std::integral_constant<
241
          bool, !(std::is_reference<T>::value ||
242
                  std::is_const<typename std::add_const<T>::type>::value)> {};
243
244
// is_trivially_destructible()
245
//
246
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially destructable.
247
//
248
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
249
// `std::is_trivially_destructible()` metafunction for platforms that have
250
// incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). On any platforms that do
251
// fully support C++11, we check whether this yields the same result as the std
252
// implementation.
253
//
254
// NOTE: the extensions (__has_trivial_xxx) are implemented in gcc (version >=
255
// 4.3) and clang. Since we are supporting libstdc++ > 4.7, they should always
256
// be present. These  extensions are documented at
257
// https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Type-Traits.html#Type-Traits.
258
template <typename T>
259
struct is_trivially_destructible
260
    : std::integral_constant<bool, __has_trivial_destructor(T) &&
261
                                   std::is_destructible<T>::value> {
262
#ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_DESTRUCTIBLE
263
 private:
264
  static constexpr bool compliant = std::is_trivially_destructible<T>::value ==
265
                                    is_trivially_destructible::value;
266
  static_assert(compliant || std::is_trivially_destructible<T>::value,
267
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_destructible; "
268
                "Standard: false, Implementation: true");
269
  static_assert(compliant || !std::is_trivially_destructible<T>::value,
270
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_destructible; "
271
                "Standard: true, Implementation: false");
272
#endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_DESTRUCTIBLE
273
};
274
275
// is_trivially_default_constructible()
276
//
277
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially default constructible.
278
//
279
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
280
// `std::is_trivially_default_constructible()` metafunction for platforms that
281
// have incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). On any platforms that
282
// do fully support C++11, we check whether this yields the same result as the
283
// std implementation.
284
//
285
// NOTE: according to the C++ standard, Section: 20.15.4.3 [meta.unary.prop]
286
// "The predicate condition for a template specialization is_constructible<T,
287
// Args...> shall be satisfied if and only if the following variable
288
// definition would be well-formed for some invented variable t:
289
//
290
// T t(declval<Args>()...);
291
//
292
// is_trivially_constructible<T, Args...> additionally requires that the
293
// variable definition does not call any operation that is not trivial.
294
// For the purposes of this check, the call to std::declval is considered
295
// trivial."
296
//
297
// Notes from https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/types/is_constructible:
298
// In many implementations, is_nothrow_constructible also checks if the
299
// destructor throws because it is effectively noexcept(T(arg)). Same
300
// applies to is_trivially_constructible, which, in these implementations, also
301
// requires that the destructor is trivial.
302
// GCC bug 51452: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=51452
303
// LWG issue 2116: http://cplusplus.github.io/LWG/lwg-active.html#2116.
304
//
305
// "T obj();" need to be well-formed and not call any nontrivial operation.
306
// Nontrivially destructible types will cause the expression to be nontrivial.
307
template <typename T>
308
struct is_trivially_default_constructible
309
    : std::integral_constant<bool, __has_trivial_constructor(T) &&
310
                                   std::is_default_constructible<T>::value &&
311
                                   is_trivially_destructible<T>::value> {
312
#ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_CONSTRUCTIBLE
313
 private:
314
  static constexpr bool compliant =
315
      std::is_trivially_default_constructible<T>::value ==
316
      is_trivially_default_constructible::value;
317
  static_assert(compliant || std::is_trivially_default_constructible<T>::value,
318
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_default_constructible; "
319
                "Standard: false, Implementation: true");
320
  static_assert(compliant || !std::is_trivially_default_constructible<T>::value,
321
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_default_constructible; "
322
                "Standard: true, Implementation: false");
323
#endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_CONSTRUCTIBLE
324
};
325
326
// is_trivially_move_constructible()
327
//
328
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially move constructible.
329
//
330
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
331
// `std::is_trivially_move_constructible()` metafunction for platforms that have
332
// incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). On any platforms that do
333
// fully support C++11, we check whether this yields the same result as the std
334
// implementation.
335
//
336
// NOTE: `T obj(declval<T>());` needs to be well-formed and not call any
337
// nontrivial operation.  Nontrivially destructible types will cause the
338
// expression to be nontrivial.
339
template <typename T>
340
struct is_trivially_move_constructible
341
    : std::conditional<
342
          std::is_object<T>::value && !std::is_array<T>::value,
343
          std::is_move_constructible<
344
              type_traits_internal::SingleMemberUnion<T>>,
345
          std::is_reference<T>>::type::type {
346
#ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_CONSTRUCTIBLE
347
 private:
348
  static constexpr bool compliant =
349
      std::is_trivially_move_constructible<T>::value ==
350
      is_trivially_move_constructible::value;
351
  static_assert(compliant || std::is_trivially_move_constructible<T>::value,
352
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_move_constructible; "
353
                "Standard: false, Implementation: true");
354
  static_assert(compliant || !std::is_trivially_move_constructible<T>::value,
355
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_move_constructible; "
356
                "Standard: true, Implementation: false");
357
#endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_CONSTRUCTIBLE
358
};
359
360
// is_trivially_copy_constructible()
361
//
362
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially copy constructible.
363
//
364
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
365
// `std::is_trivially_copy_constructible()` metafunction for platforms that have
366
// incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). On any platforms that do
367
// fully support C++11, we check whether this yields the same result as the std
368
// implementation.
369
//
370
// NOTE: `T obj(declval<const T&>());` needs to be well-formed and not call any
371
// nontrivial operation.  Nontrivially destructible types will cause the
372
// expression to be nontrivial.
373
template <typename T>
374
struct is_trivially_copy_constructible
375
    : std::conditional<
376
          std::is_object<T>::value && !std::is_array<T>::value,
377
          std::is_copy_constructible<
378
              type_traits_internal::SingleMemberUnion<T>>,
379
          std::is_lvalue_reference<T>>::type::type {
380
#ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_CONSTRUCTIBLE
381
 private:
382
  static constexpr bool compliant =
383
      std::is_trivially_copy_constructible<T>::value ==
384
      is_trivially_copy_constructible::value;
385
  static_assert(compliant || std::is_trivially_copy_constructible<T>::value,
386
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_copy_constructible; "
387
                "Standard: false, Implementation: true");
388
  static_assert(compliant || !std::is_trivially_copy_constructible<T>::value,
389
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_copy_constructible; "
390
                "Standard: true, Implementation: false");
391
#endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_CONSTRUCTIBLE
392
};
393
394
// is_trivially_move_assignable()
395
//
396
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially move assignable.
397
//
398
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
399
// `std::is_trivially_move_assignable()` metafunction for platforms that have
400
// incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). On any platforms that do
401
// fully support C++11, we check whether this yields the same result as the std
402
// implementation.
403
//
404
// NOTE: `is_assignable<T, U>::value` is `true` if the expression
405
// `declval<T>() = declval<U>()` is well-formed when treated as an unevaluated
406
// operand. `is_trivially_assignable<T, U>` requires the assignment to call no
407
// operation that is not trivial. `is_trivially_copy_assignable<T>` is simply
408
// `is_trivially_assignable<T&, T>`.
409
template <typename T>
410
struct is_trivially_move_assignable
411
    : std::conditional<
412
          std::is_object<T>::value && !std::is_array<T>::value,
413
          std::is_move_assignable<type_traits_internal::SingleMemberUnion<T>>,
414
          type_traits_internal::IsTriviallyMoveAssignableReference<T>>::type::
415
          type {
416
#ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_ASSIGNABLE
417
 private:
418
  static constexpr bool compliant =
419
      std::is_trivially_move_assignable<T>::value ==
420
      is_trivially_move_assignable::value;
421
  static_assert(compliant || std::is_trivially_move_assignable<T>::value,
422
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_move_assignable; "
423
                "Standard: false, Implementation: true");
424
  static_assert(compliant || !std::is_trivially_move_assignable<T>::value,
425
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_move_assignable; "
426
                "Standard: true, Implementation: false");
427
#endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_ASSIGNABLE
428
};
429
430
// is_trivially_copy_assignable()
431
//
432
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially copy assignable.
433
//
434
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
435
// `std::is_trivially_copy_assignable()` metafunction for platforms that have
436
// incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). On any platforms that do
437
// fully support C++11, we check whether this yields the same result as the std
438
// implementation.
439
//
440
// NOTE: `is_assignable<T, U>::value` is `true` if the expression
441
// `declval<T>() = declval<U>()` is well-formed when treated as an unevaluated
442
// operand. `is_trivially_assignable<T, U>` requires the assignment to call no
443
// operation that is not trivial. `is_trivially_copy_assignable<T>` is simply
444
// `is_trivially_assignable<T&, const T&>`.
445
template <typename T>
446
struct is_trivially_copy_assignable
447
    : std::integral_constant<
448
          bool, __has_trivial_assign(typename std::remove_reference<T>::type) &&
449
                    absl::is_copy_assignable<T>::value> {
450
#ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_ASSIGNABLE
451
 private:
452
  static constexpr bool compliant =
453
      std::is_trivially_copy_assignable<T>::value ==
454
      is_trivially_copy_assignable::value;
455
  static_assert(compliant || std::is_trivially_copy_assignable<T>::value,
456
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_copy_assignable; "
457
                "Standard: false, Implementation: true");
458
  static_assert(compliant || !std::is_trivially_copy_assignable<T>::value,
459
                "Not compliant with std::is_trivially_copy_assignable; "
460
                "Standard: true, Implementation: false");
461
#endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_IS_TRIVIALLY_ASSIGNABLE
462
};
463
464
namespace type_traits_internal {
465
// is_trivially_copyable()
466
//
467
// Determines whether the passed type `T` is trivially copyable.
468
//
469
// This metafunction is designed to be a drop-in replacement for the C++11
470
// `std::is_trivially_copyable()` metafunction for platforms that have
471
// incomplete C++11 support (such as libstdc++ 4.x). We use the C++17 definition
472
// of TriviallyCopyable.
473
//
474
// NOTE: `is_trivially_copyable<T>::value` is `true` if all of T's copy/move
475
// constructors/assignment operators are trivial or deleted, T has at least
476
// one non-deleted copy/move constructor/assignment operator, and T is trivially
477
// destructible. Arrays of trivially copyable types are trivially copyable.
478
//
479
// We expose this metafunction only for internal use within absl.
480
template <typename T>
481
class is_trivially_copyable_impl {
482
  using ExtentsRemoved = typename std::remove_all_extents<T>::type;
483
  static constexpr bool kIsCopyOrMoveConstructible =
484
      std::is_copy_constructible<ExtentsRemoved>::value ||
485
      std::is_move_constructible<ExtentsRemoved>::value;
486
  static constexpr bool kIsCopyOrMoveAssignable =
487
      absl::is_copy_assignable<ExtentsRemoved>::value ||
488
      absl::is_move_assignable<ExtentsRemoved>::value;
489
490
 public:
491
  static constexpr bool kValue =
492
      (__has_trivial_copy(ExtentsRemoved) || !kIsCopyOrMoveConstructible) &&
493
      (__has_trivial_assign(ExtentsRemoved) || !kIsCopyOrMoveAssignable) &&
494
      (kIsCopyOrMoveConstructible || kIsCopyOrMoveAssignable) &&
495
      is_trivially_destructible<ExtentsRemoved>::value &&
496
      // We need to check for this explicitly because otherwise we'll say
497
      // references are trivial copyable when compiled by MSVC.
498
      !std::is_reference<ExtentsRemoved>::value;
499
};
500
501
template <typename T>
502
struct is_trivially_copyable
503
    : std::integral_constant<
504
          bool, type_traits_internal::is_trivially_copyable_impl<T>::kValue> {};
505
}  // namespace type_traits_internal
506
507

508

template <typename T>
512
using remove_cv_t = typename std::remove_cv<T>::type;
513
514
template <typename T>
515
using remove_const_t = typename std::remove_const<T>::type;
516

template <typename T>
518
using remove_volatile_t = typename std::remove_volatile<T>::type;
519

template <typename T>
521
using add_cv_t = typename std::add_cv<T>::type;
522
523
template <typename T>
524
using add_const_t = typename std::add_const<T>::type;
525

template <typename T>
527
using add_volatile_t = typename std::add_volatile<T>::type;
528

template <typename T>
530
using remove_reference_t = typename std::remove_reference<T>::type;
531

533
using add_lvalue_reference_t = typename std::add_lvalue_reference<T>::type;
534

536
using add_rvalue_reference_t = typename std::add_rvalue_reference<T>::type;
537

template <typename T>
539
using remove_pointer_t = typename std::remove_pointer<T>::type;
540
541
template <typename T>
542
using add_pointer_t = typename std::add_pointer<T>::type;
543

template <typename T>
545
using make_signed_t = typename std::make_signed<T>::type;
546

548
using make_unsigned_t = typename std::make_unsigned<T>::type;
549

551
using remove_extent_t = typename std::remove_extent<T>::type;
552

554
using remove_all_extents_t = typename std::remove_all_extents<T>::type;

template <size_t Len, size_t Align = type_traits_internal::
557
                          default_alignment_of_aligned_storage<Len>::value>
558
using aligned_storage_t = typename std::aligned_storage<Len, Align>::type;
559

template <typename T>
561
using decay_t = typename std::decay<T>::type;
562

564
using enable_if_t = typename std::enable_if<B, T>::type;
565

567
using conditional_t = typename std::conditional<B, T, F>::type;
568

570
using common_type_t = typename std::common_type<T...>::type;
571

573

576

578
namespace type_traits_internal {
579
// In MSVC we can't probe std::hash or stdext::hash because it triggers a
580
// static_assert instead of failing substitution. Libc++ prior to 4.0
581
// also used a static_assert.
582
//
583
#if defined(_MSC_VER) || (defined(_LIBCPP_VERSION) && \
584
                          _LIBCPP_VERSION < 4000 && _LIBCPP_STD_VER > 11)
585
#define ABSL_META_INTERNAL_STD_HASH_SFINAE_FRIENDLY_ 0
586
#else
587
#define ABSL_META_INTERNAL_STD_HASH_SFINAE_FRIENDLY_ 1
588
#endif
589
590
#if !ABSL_META_INTERNAL_STD_HASH_SFINAE_FRIENDLY_
591
template <typename Key, typename = size_t>
592
struct IsHashable : std::true_type {};
593
#else   // ABSL_META_INTERNAL_STD_HASH_SFINAE_FRIENDLY_
594
template <typename Key, typename = void>
595
struct IsHashable : std::false_type {};
596
597
template <typename Key>
598
struct IsHashable<
599
    Key,
600
    absl::enable_if_t<std::is_convertible<
601
        decltype(std::declval<std::hash<Key>&>()(std::declval<Key const&>())),
602
        std::size_t>::value>> : std::true_type {};
603
#endif  // !ABSL_META_INTERNAL_STD_HASH_SFINAE_FRIENDLY_
604
605
struct AssertHashEnabledHelper {
606
 private:
607
0
  static void Sink(...) {}
608
  struct NAT {};
609
610
  template <class Key>
611
  static auto GetReturnType(int)
612
      -> decltype(std::declval<std::hash<Key>>()(std::declval<Key const&>()));
613
  template <class Key>
614
  static NAT GetReturnType(...);
615
616
  template <class Key>
617
  static std::nullptr_t DoIt() {
618
    static_assert(IsHashable<Key>::value,
619
                  "std::hash<Key> does not provide a call operator");
620
    static_assert(
621
        std::is_default_constructible<std::hash<Key>>::value,
622
        "std::hash<Key> must be default constructible when it is enabled");
623
    static_assert(
624
        std::is_copy_constructible<std::hash<Key>>::value,
625
        "std::hash<Key> must be copy constructible when it is enabled");
626
    static_assert(absl::is_copy_assignable<std::hash<Key>>::value,
627
                  "std::hash<Key> must be copy assignable when it is enabled");
628
    // is_destructible is unchecked as it's implied by each of the
629
    // is_constructible checks.
630
    using ReturnType = decltype(GetReturnType<Key>(0));
631
    static_assert(std::is_same<ReturnType, NAT>::value ||
632
                      std::is_same<ReturnType, size_t>::value,
633
                  "std::hash<Key> must return size_t");
634
    return nullptr;
635
  }
636
637
  template <class... Ts>
638
  friend void AssertHashEnabled();
639
};
640
641
template <class... Ts>
642
inline void AssertHashEnabled() {
643
  using Helper = AssertHashEnabledHelper;
644
  Helper::Sink(Helper::DoIt<Ts>()...);
645
}
646
647
}  // namespace type_traits_internal
648
649
// An internal namespace that is required to implement the C++17 swap traits.
650
// It is not further nested in type_traits_internal to avoid long symbol names.
651
namespace swap_internal {
652
653
// Necessary for the traits.
654
using std::swap;
655
656
// This declaration prevents global `swap` and `absl::swap` overloads from being
657
// considered unless ADL picks them up.
658
void swap();
659
660
template <class T>
661
using IsSwappableImpl = decltype(swap(std::declval<T&>(), std::declval<T&>()));
662
663
// NOTE: This dance with the default template parameter is for MSVC.
664
template <class T,
665
          class IsNoexcept = std::integral_constant<
666
              bool, noexcept(swap(std::declval<T&>(), std::declval<T&>()))>>
667
using IsNothrowSwappableImpl = typename std::enable_if<IsNoexcept::value>::type;
668
669
// IsSwappable
670
//
671
// Determines whether the standard swap idiom is a valid expression for
672
// arguments of type `T`.
673
template <class T>
674
struct IsSwappable
675
    : absl::type_traits_internal::is_detected<IsSwappableImpl, T> {};
676
677
// IsNothrowSwappable
678
//
679
// Determines whether the standard swap idiom is a valid expression for
680
// arguments of type `T` and is noexcept.
681
template <class T>
682
struct IsNothrowSwappable
683
    : absl::type_traits_internal::is_detected<IsNothrowSwappableImpl, T> {};
684
685
// Swap()
686
//
687
// Performs the swap idiom from a namespace where valid candidates may only be
688
// found in `std` or via ADL.
689
template <class T, absl::enable_if_t<IsSwappable<T>::value, int> = 0>
690
void Swap(T& lhs, T& rhs) noexcept(IsNothrowSwappable<T>::value) {
691
  swap(lhs, rhs);
692
}
693
694
// StdSwapIsUnconstrained
695
//
696
// Some standard library implementations are broken in that they do not
697
// constrain `std::swap`. This will effectively tell us if we are dealing with
698
// one of those implementations.
699
using StdSwapIsUnconstrained = IsSwappable<void()>;
700
701
}  // namespace swap_internal
702
703
namespace type_traits_internal {
704
705
// Make the swap-related traits/function accessible from this namespace.
706
using swap_internal::IsNothrowSwappable;
707
using swap_internal::IsSwappable;
708
using swap_internal::Swap;
709
using swap_internal::StdSwapIsUnconstrained;
710
711
}  // namespace type_traits_internal
712
}  // namespace absl
713
714
#endif  // ABSL_META_TYPE_TRAITS_H_
